raw_text:
Blair looks to election campaign
 
 Tony Blair's big speech will be looked back on as the performance that kicked off the election campaign.
 
 That poll may still be about 16 weeks away, but there can be little doubt left that the campaign is now in full swing. The prime minister used his speech to a selected audience in the south east to set out his broad brush election manifesto. There was a detailed account of the government's past record, with a major emphasis on the economy and public services. There was an attempt to draw the line under the gossip surrounding his rift with Chancellor Gordon Brown. And there was an insistence on the importance of the party continuing to operate as unremittingly "New" Labour - although that may continue to irritate his chancellor.
 
 There was little in terms of concrete proposals or what might form manifesto pledges, although the prime minister talked about a "New Labour manifesto that will be aimed at all sections of society". His was more a speech designed to remind people, and some in his own party, precisely what New Labour stood for, and to leave them in no doubt there would not be any shrinking away from that approach. And, for some, that means showing that New Labour actually does stand for something - that it is, as he said, more than "an electoral device".
 
 To that end he set out a broad programme aimed to appeal to both middle England voters who switched to the party in 1997 and stuck with it, possibly through some gritted teeth, in 2001, and to more traditional lower income old Labour supporters. In a key section, he declared: "In our third term we can achieve an unprecedented widening of opportunity and prosperity. "For the first time ever a whole generation growing up with unbroken economic stability. Every family - not just the fortunate few - knowing their children will have an inheritance at adulthood. "Every pupil in every secondary school guaranteed a place in university or a quality apprenticeship. Every adult - including those who missed out at school - able to get the skills then need to advance. "Home ownership extended to its highest ever level and to families who have never before been able to afford it. "The highest ever level of employment with everyone in work guaranteed a decent wage and decent conditions".
 
 Under what is to be the general election slogan "Britain is working", the prime minister time and again insisted the future direction would be unremittingly New Labour. That might get under the skin of Mr Brown, but he also heaped praise on him as the most successful post-war chancellor Britain has had. Probably the greatest ideological divide between the two men, in so far as there is one, is about the degree of private finance allowed into the public services.
 
 An unremittingly "New" Labour manifesto, as the prime minister is happy to make plain, will stress the importance of that - the belief patients and parents, for example, want a choice of good services before they start worrying about who has provided them. The chancellor is said to be far more sceptical about private finance, although there is no suggestion he opposes it in principle. With an election looming the next big speech from Gordon Brown will be closely examined for any signs of divisions and, in particular, the use of that little three letter word. But for now, all eyes have been focused on the next general election. And for many in Westminster, Mr Blair's performance has only succeeded in hardening the belief that will be on 5 May.
llama3.2:1b: Tony Blair's speech sets out his broad election manifesto, emphasizing the government's economy and public services. The prime minister draws a line under past controversies with Chancellor Gordon Brown, insisting that New Labour stands for something more than just an electoral device. He promises to widen opportunity and prosperity, extending home ownership and guaranteeing decent wages and conditions for everyone. An "unremittingly" New Labour manifesto will stress the importance of public services being publicly funded, while private finance is seen as a way to supplement funding rather than replace it.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair's big speech marked the start of his election campaign, focusing on the economy and public services with a broad-brush manifesto outlining "New Labour" principles. He emphasized the importance of choice and private finance in public services, while also praising Chancellor Gordon Brown as the most successful post-war chancellor. The prime minister's speech aimed to reassure party members and voters that New Labour still stands for something beyond electoral politics.
gemma2:2b: Tony Blair delivered a speech outlining his New Labour platform and setting the stage for the upcoming general election.  The speech emphasized the party's commitment to "New" policies aimed at expanding opportunity and prosperity while reassuring voters about its direction. The speech also addressed the future of public services, including private finance, a key difference with Chancellor Gordon Brown who is more skeptical about it.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The prime minister outlined his manifesto to a selected audience in the south east of England and stressed New Labour’s commitment to the public sector.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Tony Blair outlines a broad New Labour election manifesto aimed at middle class and lower income voters, emphasizing economic stability and educational opportunities. Despite criticism of his relationship with Chancellor Gordon Brown, he praises him as Britain's most successful post-war chancellor. The speech is seen as preparing the ground for future elections.
qwen2.5:3b: Blair's speech highlighted his "New Labour" agenda emphasizing economic stability and public services. It aimed to appeal to both traditional Labour supporters and newer voters by promising unprecedented opportunities such as guaranteed university places, home ownership, and higher employment rates. Blair emphasized the importance of choice in public services while praising Brown for being the most successful post-war chancellor but also expressing disagreement on private finance's role. The speech is seen as setting the tone for the upcoming election, with both leaders awaiting their next major speeches to reveal internal divisions.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary should include:

1. The main idea or thesis of the text (in this case, a speech by Tony Blair)
2. A brief overview of the key points made in the text
3. Any additional information or details that are relevant to understanding the text
4. No explanations, no formatting, and no reasoning process.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this text about Tony Blair's speech as the starting point of his campaign. Let me read through it carefully.

First, the text talks about Tony Blair looking to give an election speech. The speech is part of the bigger campaign. They mention that while there are still a few weeks left on the poll, it's clear the campaign is moving forward now. Blair used his speech to set out his manifesto, which includes talking about new Labour principles.

He emphasized points like the economy and public services. There were warnings against gossip about his rift with Chancellor Gordon Brown, but he tried to keep those details hidden. The emphasis was on continuing to operate as "New" Labour, which is a bit controversial among some in his party.

Blair outlined a detailed campaign strategy. He focused on middle-class voters who switched in 1997 and stayed loyal through 2001. He also targeted traditional lower-income Labour supporters. His speech aimed to highlight opportunities for everyone—for families with unbroken economic stability, students getting degrees or apprenticeships, adults needing skills before adulthood, home ownership, and high levels of employment.

He called the overall slogan "Britain is working," which likely means supporting a different ideology from Blair's, probably New Labour. There was criticism about private finance in public services, but he didn't oppose it. The election is coming up, so people are focusing on his speech to harden their beliefs around New Labour.

I need to condense all this into a concise summary without extra information or explanations. I'll make sure to capture the main points: Blair's role, the start of the campaign, key policies he discussed, the focus on different voter segments, and his stance on New Labour.
</think>

Tony Blair's speech marks the beginning of his political career, signaling the start of his "New Labour" campaign. He emphasized economic principles and public services, urging voters to continue working towards a stable and prosperous future. His manifesto aimed to offer opportunities for middle-income families with unbroken stability, students with higher education or apprenticeships, adults transitioning into the workforce, homeowners, and those in high-level employment, highlighting New Labour's focus on choice and quality of life. The election slogan "Britain is working" likely reflected the campaign's shift from Blair's base but continued to emphasize New Labour's ideas.
tinyllama:1.1b: The prime minister used his speech to set out a broad programme aimed at addressing concerns of voters across the country. He declared an "unprecedented" wide-ranging opportunity and prosperity, with every family guaranteed an income at adulthood, home ownership extending to families who missed out at school, employment at its highest level, and an unremittingly "New" Labour manifesto that aims to deliver for all sections of society. In contrast to the chaNCelloR Brown, the prime minister's belief in private finanse is not being scrutinized, with eyes focused on the next general election.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Blair delivers a major speech as the campaign begins

Tony Blair is all set to deliver a pivotal speech aimed at rekindling New Labour's electoral base as the political season gears up for the general election. With polls showing his party trailing its rivals, the Prime Minister has no option but to use this platform to reaffirm his party's dedication to its core values and vision.

The speech will be focused on setting out the government's past record and emphasizing the party's commitment to making a difference in people's lives. Blair may also touch upon current issues such as the economy, healthcare, education, and welfare reform to appeal to a broader audience.

The rhetorical tension between the Prime Minister and his chancellor, Gordon Brown, is likely to be high as they both face increasing scrutiny from voters who are looking for a change in direction. Blair's speech could also signal his intentions for the party's future, setting out plans for an unremittingly "New" Labour manifesto that will focus on delivering for all sections of society.

In this election season, there is no doubt that Tony Blair and his team are preparing to make their case for re-election. With a general election only a few months away, the stakes are high as voters look for leaders who can unite the nation and bring about change.
phi:2.7b: The speech made by Tony Blair at a selected event in the south east was seen as the kick-off to his election campaign and emphasized the government's record on the economy and public services, while also addressing past controversies. Although there were no concrete proposals or manifesto pledges, Blair aimed to remind people of what New Labour stood for and leave little room for shrinking away from that approach. He set out a broad program aimed at both middle-class and lower-income voters, emphasizing economic stability, increased access to education, and expanded home ownership. The emphasis on New Labour's unwavering stance may be seen as a move to appease his chancellor, who is more skeptical about private finance in the public services.
orca-mini:3b: Blair looks to election campaign with a speech to a selected audience in the south east, setting out his broad brush election manifesto and emphasizing the importance of private finance in public services. He also praised Chancellor Gordon Brown as the most successful post-war chancellor Britain has had. Blair's speech focused on the government's past record, emphasizing the economy and public services. There was a clear attempt to draw the line under the gossip surrounding his rift with Brown, and Blair reiterated the importance of New Labour continuing to operate as unremittingly "New" Labour. The speech left no doubt that the campaign is now in full swing and focused on an unremittingly "New" Labour manifesto that will appeal to middle England voters and traditional lower income old Labour supporters.
hermes3:3b: Tony Blair delivers full-swing election manifesto speech, emphasizing New Labour approach to appeal both middle-class and traditional labor supporters.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Tony Blair kicked off the election campaign with a speech outlining his broad manifesto centered around the economy and public services. He aimed to remind people of New Labour values and appeal to both middle-class voters who switched parties in 1997 and traditional old Labour supporters. The future direction under the slogan "Britain is working" will emphasize the importance of choice in healthcare services, as well as maintaining a focus on New Labour principles. This performance only strengthened beliefs that the election will take place on May 5th.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Tony Blair's speech effectively launched the election campaign, emphasizing New Labour's achievements and future direction. He highlighted economic stability, expanded home ownership, improved education opportunities, and employment growth. Blair sought to reaffirm New Labour's identity and downplay tensions with Chancellor Gordon Brown, despite differences over private finance in public services. The speech aimed to appeal to both middle-class and traditional Labour voters under the slogan "Britain is working." With the election expected on 5 May, attention now turns to Brown's response and any signs of division within the party.
stablelm2:1.6b:
Blair kicks off election campaign with big speech: PM sets out election manifesto focusing on economy and public services, appealing to middle England voters and traditional lower income old Labour supporters. He promises a "New Labour" program for opportunities and prosperity, such..
- Britain is working slogan
- Unremittingly New Labour manifesto emphasizes choice of good services
- PM's performance hardens belief that New Labour stands for something more than an electoral device
granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Blair delivered a significant speech to a select audience in southeast England, marking the beginning of the general election campaign, slated for 5 May. His address served as an overview of New Labour's past achievements and future goals, emphasizing economic stability, improved public services, and increased opportunities for all sections of society. Blair aimed to reaffirm his party's commitment to "New" Labour principles, ensuring it is not merely an electoral tool but a coherent ideology. He proposed expanding home ownership, guaranteeing adult education and employment, and maintaining the highest employment rates with decent wages and conditions. Blair praised Chancellor Gordon Brown as the most successful post-war chancellor, highlighting their shared belief in private finance for quality public services. The speech underscored Britain's potential to reach unprecedented levels of opportunity and prosperity under New Labour's guidance.
